evidence.dc:description:
Samples from the proband (K498fs) and two other individuals with HMWK deficiency were diluted 1:10, reduced with 2-ME and run on 7% SDS-PAGE. Samples were electroblotted onto nitrocellulose and incubated with a polyclonal antibody specific for HMWK.  
No band (120kDa) was observed in the proband or either of the other affected individuals.  Control plasma showed a strong band at approproriate weight and plasma from family members of the proband had visible, although reduced bands.  These family members are all heterozygous for the variant.

dc:source.dc:abstract: A 6-year-old male with vertebral-basilar artery thrombosis was recognized to have high-molecular-weight kininogen (HK) deficiency. The propositus had no HK procoagulant activity and antigen (< 1%). Using monoclonal antibodies (Mabs) to kininogen domain 3, the propositus, family members, and Fitzgerald plasma were determined to have detectable low-molecular-weight kininogen. Mabs to HK domains 5 and 6 do not detect HK antigen in the propositus' plasma. The propositus has a single base pair (bp) deletion in cDNA position 1492 of exon 10 affecting amino acid 480 of the mature protein and resulting in a frameshift and a premature stop codon at position 1597 (amino acid 532). Unexpectedly, Mabs to the heavy chain and domain 5 of HK detect a 92-kDa form of HK in Fitzgerald plasma, the first HK-deficient plasma. The 92-kDa Fitzgerald HK has amino acid residues through 502, corresponding to domains 1 through 5, but lacks epitopes of domain 6 (positions 543 to 595). Fitzgerald DNA has a normal exon 10, but a 17-bp mutation in intron 9. These combined results indicate that mutations in the kininogen gene may differentially affect biosynthesis, processing, and/or secretion of HK.
dc:source.dc:creator: Krijanovski Y
dc:source.dc:title: Characterization of molecular defects of Fitzgerald trait and another novel high-molecular-weight kininogen-deficient patient: insights into structural requirements for kininogen expression.

evidence.rdfs:label: Krijanovski - Immunoblotting

evidence.dc:description: Eight mKng1-/- mice and 8 mKng1 WT mice were assessed for aPTT.  The average value from the WT mice was 24.5 (+/-2.2) seconds, whereas the average value from the mKng1-/- mice was 54.11 (+/- 11.5) seconds.

dc:source.dc:abstract: High-molecular-weight kininogen (HK) plays an important role in the assembly of the plasma kallikrein-kinin system. While the human genome contains a single copy of the kininogen gene, 3 copies exist in the rat (1 encoding K-kininogen and 2 encoding T-kininogen). Here, we confirm that the mouse genome contains 2 homologous kininogen genes, mKng1 and mKng2, and demonstrate that these genes are expressed in a tissue-specific manner. To determine the roles of these genes in murine development and physiology, we disrupted mKng1, which is expressed primarily in the liver. mKng1(-/-) mice were viable, but lacked plasma HK and low-molecular-weight kininogen (LK), as well as DeltamHK-D5, a novel kininogen isoform that lacks kininogen domain 5. Moreover, despite normal tail vein bleeding times, mKng1(-/-) mice displayed a significantly prolonged time to carotid artery occlusion following Rose Bengal administration and laser-induced arterial injury. These results suggest that a single gene, mKng1, is responsible for production of plasma kininogen, and that plasma HK contributes to induced arterial thrombosis in mice.
dc:source.dc:creator: Merkulov S
dc:source.dc:title: Deletion of murine kininogen gene 1 (mKng1) causes loss of plasma kininogen and delays thrombosis.

evidence.rdfs:label: Merkulov - Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: The mouse model recapitulated the human phenotype of prolonged aPTT. The mKng1-/- mice did not demonstrate any significant phenotype, including bleeding. Further, the mKng1-/- mice showed a significant decrease in time to thrombosis (21.4 +/- 3.8 minutes) compared to the WT animals (10.6 +/- 3.6 minutes), suggesting protection.  This has not been studied in humans, and to the contrary, some instances of thrombosis in humans with HMWK deficiency have been reported.

evidence.detectionMethod: Exon 10 of the KNG1 gene was amplified and Sanger sequenced.  Due to previous testing (restriction sites), exon 10 was the only exon targeted.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Coagulation assays including aPTT, PT, HMWK, and "other clotting factors".  Her aPTT was prolonged and her prekallikrein  was decreased.  Other clotting factors were normal.

dc:source.dc:creator: Shigekiyo T
dc:source.dc:title: Isolated high-molecular-weight kininogen deficiency: a novel frameshift mutation in exon 10.

evidence.rdfs:label: Shigekiyo Proband

evidence.dc:description: The variant, KNG1 c.1216dup, p.H406Pfs*10 results in a premature stop codon.  This premature stop codon results is a truncated KNG1 protein missing >35% of the amino acid sequence.  This variant is not found in the general population (gnomAD). Points were downgraded due to this variant not causing NMD.

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic PCR was amplified and digested with Csp451. The PCR products were subcloned into the pCR-Blunt vector.  Sequencing was performed by the ABI 3730 DNA sequencer using PRISM dye Terminator Cycle Sequence Ready Reaction Kit. Two clones were sequenced to eliminate error.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The patient was known to have undetectable levels of kininogen. PMID: 3853954 and 3246722 describe the patients.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Kininogens are multifunctional plasma glycoproteins. There are two forms of human kininogen: low molecular weight kininogen (LK) and high molecular weight kininogen (HK). Both are derived from the same gene by alternative splicing. Some patients with kininogen deficiency have been reported to be deficient only in HK while others are deficient in both HK and LK (total kininogen deficiency). We analyzed three Japanese patients with total kininogen deficiency by the Csp45I digestion study of exon 5 as previously reported in Williams trait and found that two had the same point mutation of C to T at base 22 of exon 5, resulting in a transition of CGA (Arg) codon to TGA (Stop) codon. This is the first report of molecular characterization of total kininogen deficiency in the Japanese population.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ishimaru F
dc:source.dc:title: Molecular characterization of total kininogen deficiency in Japanese patients.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ishimaru - Proband (B2)

evidence.dc:description: he variant, c.586C>T, p.Arg196* results in a premature stop codon. This premature stop codon is predicted to result in nonsense mediated mRNA decay. The minor allele frequency of this variant in the general population is 0.00001061 (GnomAD).  This variant is reported in an additional proband in this paper (B4), however, both are from Japan, so a common ancestor cannot be ruled out.  This variant is also reported in Cheung et al, PMID:7901207, and was included in this curation.

evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing of all exons of the KNG1 gene and flanking regions was performed.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Coagulation assays including aPTT, PT, FVIII, FIX, FXI, FXIII, PK, HMWK were performed. The prolonged aPTT was fully corrected in mixing studies. Factors VIII, IX, and XII activities were all within normal range. Factor XI activity was slightly decreased.  To rule out immunologic reasons for a prolonged aPTT, lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin antibody, anti-beta2GPI antibody, and ANA were performed. All were negative.

dc:source.dc:creator: Jeong D
dc:source.dc:title: The First Korean Case of High-Molecular-Weight Kininogen Deficiency, With a Novel Variant, c.488delG, in the

evidence.rdfs:label: Jeong-Proband

evidence.dc:description: The compound heterozygous variants, KNG1 c.488delG, p.Gly163Alafs*20 and c.1165C>T, p.Arg389* both result in premature stop codons.  These premature stop codons are predicted to result in loss of function by mRNA decay. Variant p.Gly163Alafs*20 is reported at a frequency of 0.000007954 and variant p.Arg389* is reported at a frequency of 0.000008079 (gnomAD).

evidence.detectionMethod: Amplification and sequencing of the coding and intronic regions of KNG1 was performed.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Coagulation and fibrinolytic assays, including PTT, FII, FV FVII, FVIII, FIX, FXI, FXII, fibrinogen, fibrinogen degradation, plasminogen, kallikrein, and thrombin time.  The prolonged PTT was corrected with  mixing studies.

dc:source.dc:abstract: High and low molecular weight kininogens (HK and LK) modulate inflammatory responses, serve as precursors of kinins, inhibit cysteine proteinases, and modulate thrombin activation of platelets. Differential splicing yields two different mRNAs for HK and LK. We report the first molecular characterization of a kininogen gene mutation in a patient lacking LK and HK. No gross DNA deletion or insertion was detected by Southern blots, and LK and HK mRNAs were normal size on Northern blots. Exon sequences amplified by polymerase chain reaction showed a C-->T transition at nucleotide 587, resulting in a CGA (Arg)--> TGA (Stop) mutation in exon 5 before the splice site in exon 10, thus preventing synthesis of both HK and LK. The mutation eliminated the recognition site of the restriction enzyme Csp45I. Results of Csp45I digestion of the polymerase chain reaction-amplified exon 5 DNA fragment of the patient (lacking kininogens), three daughters (approximately 50% HK), and 1 granddaughter (normal HK) revealed that the patient was homozygous, while the three daughters were heterozygous, and the granddaughter was normal. We conclude that a single base mutation in the kininogen gene exon 5 was responsible for kininogen deficiency in the Williams family.
dc:source.dc:creator: Cheung PP
dc:source.dc:title: Genetic basis of total kininogen deficiency in Williams' trait.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cheung - Proband

evidence.dc:description: The variant, c.586C>T, p.Arg196* results in a premature stop codon.  This premature stop codon is predicted to result in nonsense mediated mRNA decay. The minor allele frequency of this variant in the general population is 0.00001061 (GnomAD).

evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted capture sequencing assay was used to look at 128 genes associated with bleeding and thrombotic disorders.  Sequencing was performed on Illumina HiSeq 2000.  All variants were confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Coagulation assays including aPTT, FVIII, FIX, FXI, FXIII, PK, HMWK were performed.  The prolonged aPTT was fully corrected in mixing studies.  Factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII activities were all within normal range.

dc:source.dc:abstract: High-molecular-weight kininogen (HMWK) deficiency is a very rare hereditary disorder caused by a defect of Kininogen-1 gene (KGN1). A 67-year-old asymptomatic male with an isolated prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) was recognized to have HMWK deficiency. The propositus had less than 1% HMWK procoagulant activity. The plasma HMWK procoagulant activities of his 2 younger sisters were 1.1% and less than 1%, respectively. Prekallikrein (PK) activity was also reduced in the propositus and two of his younger sisters with severe HMWK deficiency. Genetic testing to identify the KGN1 mutation provides a precise diagnosis for the patient and other family members. This Chinese family has a novel KGN1 nonsense variant, C to T, at nucleotide position 1456 leading to a stop codon in position 486 (p. Gln486*).
dc:source.dc:creator: Yang J
dc:source.dc:title: Severe high-molecular-weight kininogen deficiency due to a homozygous c.1456C > T nonsense variant in a large Chinese family.

evidence.rdfs:label: Yang - II-1

evidence.dc:description: The variant, KNG1 c.1456C>T, p.Q486* results in a premature stop codon.  This premature stop codon is predicted to truncate the KNG1 protein by 25%.  This variant is not reported in the general population (gnomAD).  Points were downgraded due to this variant not causing NMD.

evidence.detectionMethod: Amplification and Sanger sequencing of exon 10 of the KNG1 gene was performed.  Previous immunoblot studies indicated that the defect in this proband's plasma were contained with domain 5 or 6, which are both in exon 10.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Patient presented with cephalgia and vomiting 10 days after cervical trauma that included loss of consciousness and visual impairment.  Patient underwent CAT scan and was found to have an extensive vertebral-basilar artery thrombosis and left vertebral artery dissection. 
Coagulation assays were performed including aPTT, PT, fibrinogen, FII, V, VII, VIII, IX,X, XI, XII, antithrombin heparin cofactor activity, protein C activity, plasminogen amidolytic activity, lupus anticoagulant, protein S antigen, prekallikrein, HMWK, and VWF activity.
The only notable findings were a prolonged aPTT (corrected with mixing studies), mildly decreased prekallikrein activity and antigen (could be a shipping defect), decreased FXII activity (0.35U/mL), and virtually absent HMWK procoagulant activity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Krijanovski - Proband

evidence.dc:description: The variant, KNG1 c.1493del, p.Lys498Serfs*54 results in a premature stop codon.  This stop codon results in a truncated KNG1 protein, removing 15% if the amino acid sequence.  This variant is reported in the literature as c.1492del. This variant is not reported in the general population (gnomAD). Points were downgraded due to this variant not causing NMD.

evidence.detectionMethod: Amplification and Sanger sequencing of all exons and exon-intron junctions of KNG1 was performed.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Proband presented with pain in upper abdomen and it was discovered that he had a splenic infarction by computed tomography. Coagulation and fibrinolytic assays including CBC, PT, aPTT, fibrinogen, antithrombin, thrombin, anti-cardiolipin antibody, lupus anticoagulant, protein C, protein S, Factors II, V, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII HMWK, and PK were performed.  All testing was unremarkable with the exception of a slightly reduced FXI.  HIs aPTT was severely prolonged.  Lupus anticoagulant and clotting factor inhibitors were ruled out as the cause of the prolonged aPTT.

dc:source.dc:abstract: High-molecular-weight kininogen (HMWK) deficiency is a very rare hereditary disorder. We herein report a case of HMWK deficiency with splenic infarction. The HMWK activity of the proband was markedly decreased (0.9%). Direct sequencing of his HMWK gene showed a homozygous "TC" insertion at c523-524 in exon 4. This insertion led to an amino acid substitution, Ser175Ser, resulting in a frameshift mutation and a premature stop codon in amino acid 183. Furthermore, the HMWK activity was also reduced in the patient's three children, who exhibited the heterozygous "TC" insertion at c523-524 in exon 4. This is the first report of this gene alteration in a patient with HMWK deficiency.
dc:source.dc:creator: Fukushima N
dc:source.dc:title: A novel frameshift mutation in exon 4 causing a deficiency of high-molecular-weight kininogen in a patient with splenic infarction.

evidence.rdfs:label: Fukushima - Proband

evidence.dc:description: The variant, KNG1 c.523_524insTC, p.Ser175PhefsTer9 results in a premature stop codon. This premature stop codon is predicted to result in nonsense mediated mRNA decay. This variant is not seen in the general population (GnomAD).

dc:description: KNG1 was first reported in relation to high molecular weight kininogen (HMWK) deficiency in 1990 (Hayashi et al, PMID: 1968772). This curation is considered a gene-deficiency curation, due to the lack of evidence supporting this gene being involved in any disease or disorder beyond a prolonged PTT. Evidence supporting this gene-deficiency curation includes case-level data, segregation data, and experimental data.  At least 6 unique variants (nonsense and frameshift) have been reported in humans.   Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 8 probands in over 8 publications.  Variants in this gene segregated with kininogen deficiency in 2 additional family members.  The gene-deficiency relationship is supported by an animal model (Merkulov et al, PMID: 18000168) and expression studies (Krijanovski et al, PMID: 12576314). In summary, KNG1 is definitively associated with (high molecular weight) kininogen deficiency. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and the clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time.
